@junrao I made an attempt to try to ignore the configuration when see message.timestamp.difference.max.ms is greater than retention.ms. But it is a little tricky (as explained below), so I just added a warning without ignoring the configurations.

When we see an invalid configuration there are three options:
1. Ignore that invalid configuration and keep the current configured value.
2. Ignore the invalid configuration and use default value instead.
3. Ignore all the new properties user provided, i.e keep the configurations not changed.

MessageFormatVersion is using the second option. This is actually a little dangerous. For example, if user is running Kafka 0.10.1.0 at IBP 0.10.0, currently using message format 0.9.0, and now they want to configure the message format to 0.10.1, if the configuration failed, the broker will start to use the default message format version 0.10.0 (same as IBP version). So the user may accidentally upgrade  to message format 0.10.0. I'll file another ticket for that issue.

For the retention.ms and message.timestamp.difference.max.ms, option 1 is probably the most intuitive option, but this will cause discrepancy between the configurations stored in ZK and the configurations actually used by Kafka. Arguably we already have this issue in message.format.version, but those two configurations seems have a worse impact.

I think we should probably use option 3 and hopefully KIP-4 will solve this issue, i.e. either all the configurations are taken or non of them are used and the user gets a clear exception.

But these are not blockers, so LGTM.

Hi @ijuma 
I have made the following changes
1. Set eclipse output to go to build_eclipse directory
2. Moved the classpath pruning code to a method
3. Added comments explaining purpose of the changes

Please review.

@jeyhunkarimov What I meant for javadocs updates is to include this semantic in it as well. For example, in `KStream.join` we had the following comments:

```
* If an {@link KStream} input record key or value is {@code null} the record will not be included in the join
* operation and thus no output record will be added to the resulting {@link KStream}.
```

But we do not similar explanations in `KTable.join` operator.

Maybe we can do it in a follow-up pass after it is merged, cc @mjsax .
